items.title: Deforestazione, ancora un rinvio per il regolamento UE
items.description:
Tra il 2018 e il 2022, il 36% della deforestazione globale è avvenuta in Amazzonia, dove sono stati distrutti 8,6 milioni di ettari di foresta 
The po
items.body: In evidenza Il Panda Siamo Noi In evidenza Il leopardo delle Nevi In evidenza Adotta una specie Le proteste del WWF Tra il 2018 e il 2022, il 36% della deforestazione globale è avvenuta in Amazzonia, dove sono stati distrutti 8,6 milioni di ettari di foresta (un’area più grande dell’Austria). Il 78% della superficie deforestata è dovuta all’espansione degli allevamenti bovini, principale driver della deforestazione amazzonica. Al secondo posto la coltivazione di soia (4,6%). Nell’Amazzonia centro-orientale (soprattutto in Brasile) domina l’espansione delle aree di pascolo, mentre in quella occidentale (Bolivia, Perù, Ecuador) sono in rapida crescita la coltivazione di mais, palma da olio e altre colture industriali. Ad avere un enorme impatto sono le catene di approvvigionamento globali e i consumi dell’UE. In media, nel triennio 2020–2022, gli Stati membri sono stati responsabili di circa il 20% della deforestazione per alcune commodities. Particolarmente rilevanti sono le importazioni di soia, mais e cacao. Fra i principali colpevoli c’è anche l’Italia: per soddisfare i nostri consumi, ogni anno rasi al suolo 4.000 ettari di foresta amazzonica (circa 5000 campi da calcio), pari al 10% della deforestazione incorporata totale annua del nostro Paese. Questi sono alcuni dei dati chiave dell’“Amazon Footprint Report 2025”, presentato alla Conferenza sul Clima COP30 di Belém da WWF, Trase, Chalmers University of Technology e Stockholm Environment Institute. Si tratta della prima analisi transfrontaliera che esamina l’andamento complessivo della deforestazione amazzonica e il suo legame diretto con le diverse filiere agricole. L’UE non può temporeggiare sulla tutela delle foreste Il report evidenzia con assoluta chiarezza quanto le nostre catene di approvvigionamento siano profondamente intrecciate con la distruzione della foresta amazzonica che ha già perso negli ultimi decenni il 17% della sua estensione originaria. Se vogliamo evitare gli scenari più drammatici del riscaldamento globale, vanno tutelate al più presto. Ciò significa ripensare radicalmente le filiere di produzione e i nostri consumi, per renderle sostenibili e trasparenti: una condizione chiave per salvaguardare clima, biodiversità ed il futuro dell’essere umano. Secondo WWF Italia, è quindi cruciale che l’Unione Europea non rinvii né indebolisca le misure previste per contrastare la deforestazione. Infatti, mentre l’UE si dice impegnata in Brasile alla COP30 per garantire questa tutela, alcuni Stati membri a Bruxelles stanno cercando di remare contro corrente. «La normativa europea contro la deforestazione (EUDR) è lo strumento più efficace a disposizione dell’Europa per assumersi le proprie responsabilità. Ma mentre la comunità internazionale a Belém discute di come arrestare la deforestazione e il cambiamento climatico, l’UE rischia di smantellare il suo contributo più significativo al contrasto della deforestazione globale. Ogni tentativo di rinvio o annacquamento dell’EUDR minerebbe la credibilità europea. È il momento di dimostrare leadership, non di arretrare», dichiara Edoardo Nevola, Responsabile Ufficio Foreste del WWF Italia. Un ritardo di un anno nell’entrata in vigore del Regolamento comporterebbe l’abbattimento di circa 50 milioni di alberi nel mondo ed emissioni pari a 16.8 milioni di tonnellate di gas serra (ovvero quelle emesse in tre anni da Londra e New York insieme): tanto provoca un anno di consumi dell’UE. La normativa UE contro la deforestazione (EUDR) Il Regolamento UE sui prodotti “deforestation-free” (EUDR) è entrata in vigore il 29 giugno 2023. Il suo avvio operativo è stato già posticipato una volta, a dicembre 2024, e sarà quindi applicato dal 30 dicembre 2025 alle medie e grandi imprese, e dal 30 giugno 2026 anche alle piccole e microimprese L’obiettivo è ridurre drasticamente la deforestazione globale connessa ai consumi europeo. Le imprese dovranno dimostrare che prodotti come carne bovina, cacao, caffè, olio di palma, soia, legno e gomma non provengono da superfici forestali precedentemente convertite o degradate, né da attività condotte illegalmente. Report deforestazione Amazon footprint: il report del WWF Internazionale Per saperne di più

items.title: Cop 30. Italia scende al 46esimo posto nella classifica delle performance mondiali climatiche
items.description: Presentato alla COP30 il rapporto annuale Germanwacth 2026. Italia retrocede in 46esima posizione perdendo tre posizioni nella classifica delle perfo
items.body:
18 Novembre 2025

Legambiente

18 Novembre 2025

Comunicati stampa

Crisi climatica

Cop 30. Italia scende al 46esimo posto nella classifica delle performance mondiali climatiche

18 Novembre 2025

Legambiente

18 Novembre 2025

Comunicati stampa

Crisi climatica

Presentato alla COP30 il rapporto annuale Germanwacth 2026. Italia retrocede in 46esima posizione perdendo tre posizioni nella classifica delle performance mondiali climatiche ed è sempre più lontana dalle prime, Danimarca, Regno Unito e Marocco.  Maglia nera per Stati Uniti, Iran ed Arabia Saudita, nel terzetto di coda. La Cina risale di una posizione. 
 Legambiente: “L’azione climatica globale fa progressi, ma i Paesi procedono troppo lentamente nel raggiungere gli obiettivi climatici. L’Italia paga lo scotto di una visione politica miope. Serve una svolta green per fare dell’Italia un hub delle rinnovabili e contrastare l’emergenza climatica”.  
Il report completo 
A dieci anni dall’Accordo di Parigi, l’azione climatica globale fa progressi ma i paesi del mondo procedono troppo lentamente nel raggiungere gli obiettivi preposti. E l’Italia continua a perdere terreno. La conferma arriva dalla classifica “Climate Change Performance Index 2026” stilata dal rapporto Germanwatch, CAN e NewClimate Institute, realizzato in collaborazione con Legambiente per l’Italia, e presentato oggi alla COP30 in Brasile. Nel 2025 la Penisola retrocede al 46 esimo posto in classifica, perdendo tre posizioni rispetto allo scorso anno (era 43esima) e ben 17 rispetto al 2022 (quando era 29esima). Una caduta libera che la fa restare anche quest’anno ben lontana dalle posizioni di vertice che vedono dominare la Danimarca (4°), seguita da Regno Unito (5°) e Marocco (6°). La Penisola paga lo scotto di una politica climatica nazionale (58° posto della specifica classifica) fortemente inadeguata a fronteggiare l’emergenza climatica. Infatti, l’aggiornamento del Piano Nazionale Integrato Energia e Clima (PNIEC) consente una riduzione complessiva delle emissioni entro il 2030 di appena il 44.3% e del 49.5% se si includono anche gli assorbimenti di carbonio del settore LULUCF. Un ulteriore passo indietro rispetto al 51% previsto dal PNRR, già inadeguato in confronto all’obiettivo europeo del 55%. Piano che per di più stenta a decollare, come emerge anche dal rapporto Ispra sullo Stato dell’Ambiente in Italia 2025.
Il commento
“Quanto emerge dal report Germanwacth 2026 – commenta Stefano Ciafani, presidente nazionale di Legambiente – conferma quanto poco stia facendo l’Italia nel contrasto alla crisi climatica. Sul fronte energetico il nostro Paese continua ad avere una visione miope che sta facendo fare solo passi indietro anche nella lotta alla crisi climatica, creando al tempo stesso nuove dipendenze energetiche dall’estero, da Paesi instabili politicamente. Il governo Meloni usi buon senso e non dimentichi che la Penisola può diventare un hub delle rinnovabili attraverso un modello fondato su fonti pulite, reti, accumuli ed efficienza. Solo così sarà possibile vincere la sfida della duplice crisi, energetica e climatica, che rischia di mettere in ginocchio l’Italia e compromettere la competitività della nostra economia”.
Focus Italia
Nel periodo 1990-2023 le emissioni climalteranti italiane sono diminuite del 26.4% e con le politiche correnti, secondo le proiezioni Ispra, entro il 2030 sarà possibile una riduzione delle emissioni nazionali di solo il 42%, includendo anche gli assorbimenti. Ritardo dovuto anche alla crescita ancora lenta delle rinnovabili. Nel 2023 la quota del consumo da fonti rinnovabili, sul consumo finale lordo di energia, si è attestato ad appena il 19.6%, performance fortemente inadeguata a raggiungere l’obiettivo del 39.4% previsto dal PNIEC. L’Ispra sottolinea, infatti, che il ritmo di crescita delle rinnovabili dovrebbe essere circa quattro volte superiore rispetto al passato per centrare l’obiettivo del PNIEC.
“Un Piano – commenta Mauro Albrizio, responsabile ufficio europeo Legambiente e inviato alla COP30 – poco ambizioso anche nelle soluzioni, che si nasconde dietro il dito del pragmatismo e della neutralità tecnologica posticipando il phase-out del carbone addirittura al 2038 e ricorrendo ancora una volta a false soluzioni (come la CCS e il nucleare) che faranno solo perdere tempo e risorse al nostro Paese, rischiando inoltre di rendere sempre meno competitiva l’Italia sia a livello europeo che internazionale”.
Classifica globale
Tornando al report, lo studio prende in considerazione la performance climatica di 63 Paesi, più l’Unione Europea nel suo complesso, che insieme rappresentano oltre il 90% delle emissioni globali. La performance è misurata, attraverso il Climate Change Performance Index (CCPI), prendendo come parametro di riferimento gli obiettivi dell’Accordo di Parigi e gli impegni assunti al 2030. Il CCPI si basa per il 40% sul trend delle emissioni, per il 20% sullo sviluppo sia delle rinnovabili che dell’efficienza energetica e per il restante 20% sulla politica climatica. Anche quest’anno le prime tre posizioni della classifica non sono state attribuite, in quanto nessuno dei Paesi ha ancora raggiunto la performance necessaria per contribuire a contenere con efficacia il surriscaldamento del pianeta entro la soglia critica di 1.5°C. Si conferma in testa alla classifica con il quarto posto la Danimarca, grazie soprattutto alla significativa riduzione delle emissioni climalteranti ed allo sviluppo delle rinnovabili, soprattutto offshore. Segue il Regno Unito (5°) grazie ad una più ambiziosa politica climatica ed al phase-out del carbone, nonostante il ritardo nello sviluppo delle rinnovabili. Sale il Marocco che si posiziona nel terzetto di testa (6°) con un’efficace politica climatica che garantisce emissioni pro-capite molto basse e consistenti investimenti nel trasporto pubblico. Anche quest’anno, i Paesi esportatori e utilizzatori di combustibili fossili si posizionano in coda alla classifica dove troviamo, subito dopo la Russia, Stati Uniti, Iran ed Arabia Saudita.
Paesi G20 e Cina 
Tra i Paesi del G20, responsabili del 75% delle emissioni globali e con un ruolo cruciale per contrastare la crisi climatica, solo il Regno Unito è nella parte alta della classifica. Mentre in basso si posizionano Sudafrica, Indonesia, Italia. Ed in fondo alla classifica Turchia, Cina, Australia, Giappone, Argentina, Canada, Sud-Corea, Russia, Usa e Arabia Saudita. La Cina, maggiore responsabile delle emissioni globali, sale al 54° posto, appena una posizione rispetto allo scorso. Nonostante il grande sviluppo delle rinnovabili, insieme a batterie ed auto elettriche, le emissioni cinesi crescono ancora per il continuo ricorso al carbone. Tuttavia, nel primo trimestre di quest’anno si è registrato un loro declino. Segnale che probabilmente le emissioni cinesi abbiano raggiunto il picco grazie al crescente contributo delle tecnologie pulite. La peggiore performance climatica, tra i grandi emettitori globali, quest’anno è quella dell’India (23°) che scende di ben 13 posizioni. Nonostante il promettente trend delle rinnovabili, le emissioni continuano ad aumentare per il crescente ricorso al carbone, con nuove centrali in programma e senza una roadmap per il suo phase-out.
L’Unione Europea 
L’Unione europea (20°) scende di tre posizioni, con solo 15 Paesi nella parte medio-alta. Nonostante il significativo passo in avanti della Spagna (14°) che sale di 5 posizioni per la crescente efficacia della sua politica climatica ed energetica. Performance Ue condizionata dalla Germania, maggiore economia europea, che scende di ben 6 posizioni (22°), soprattutto per il programma di nuovi impianti a gas, che rischia di compromettere i considerevoli progressi nelle rinnovabili.
LIVE Instagram

items.title: Italia sott’acqua ma il Governo non agisce sul clima
items.description:
La disattenzione del governo sulla crisi climatica, che ancora una volta sta devastando il nostro Paese, aumenta l’insicurezza dei cittadini
The post
items.body: In evidenza Il Panda Siamo Noi In evidenza Il leopardo delle Nevi In evidenza Adotta una specie WWF chiede stop allo spreco di fondi per opere inutili Proprio mentre è in corso la COP30 in Brasile, il principale appuntamento internazionale per la lotta al cambiamento climatico, gli eventi estremi di questo fine settimana e quelli in corso, ci ricordano come in Italia non sia più rinviabile affrontare seriamente la crisi climatica, sia in termini di mitigazione (abbattimento delle emissioni di CO2 e metano), sia in termini di adattamento. Il governo invece continua a ritardare e perfino contrastare le azioni contro l’emergenza climatica: così aumenta lo stato di insicurezza della popolazione e il rischio di danni sempre più gravi davanti ai quali i cittadini si sentono sempre più soli. Negli ultimi giorni alluvioni si sono abbattute su diverse regioni del Centro-Nord. Dalla Toscana al Friuli-Venezia Giulia, dalla Liguria al Veneto, questi eventi estremi hanno causato allagamenti, crolli e disagi. Purtroppo, anche la sicurezza delle persone è stata messa a repentaglio: in Friuli-Venezia Giulia, a seguito di una frana di fango che ha travolto un’abitazione risultano al momento disperse due persone, mentre un’altra è stata ferita. I danni sono anche economici: un esempio eclatante arriva purtroppo da Brazzano di Cormons (Gorizia). Tra i tanti cittadini che in queste ore stanno affrontando gravi danni a causa delle piogge torrenziali e delle alluvioni c’è anche la chef stellata Antonia Klugmann, che ha subito l’allagamento dei locali del suo ristorante “L’Argine a Vencò”: a lei e a tutte le persone che si trovano in grave difficoltà va la solidarietà della comunità WWF. Alla Cop 30 il primo documento per contrastare il negazionismo Questi eventi ci ricordano quanto sia importante intervenire per contrastare la crisi climatica. Per farlo serve però che tutti siano costantemente e correttamente informati. Non a caso la scorsa settimana, nel corso della COP30, è stato siglato il primo documento internazionale volto a contrastare la disinformazione e il negazionismo sul cambiamento climatico e a promuovere la diffusione di dati accurati e basati su evidenze scientifiche. Dieci Paesi, tra cui Brasile, Canada, Cile, Danimarca, Finlandia, Francia, Germania, Spagna, Svezia e Uruguay, hanno firmato alla COP30 una Dichiarazione sull’integrità dell’informazione climatica. La dichiarazione, sostenuta dalle Nazioni Unite e dall’Unesco, stabilisce una serie di impegni comuni per garantire la qualità delle informazioni ambientali, finanziando ricerche e programmi di formazione, soprattutto nei Paesi in via di sviluppo. Secondo il segretario generale dell’Onu, António Guterres, la nuova iniziativa globale rappresenta “un passo decisivo per garantire che scienziati e ricercatori non debbano temere di dire la verità”. Il Governo non fa passi avanti per combattere crisi climatica Il WWF si chiede e chiede come mai l’Italia non abbia sottoscritto la dichiarazione. L’azione del governo sul contrasto alla crisi climatica è insoddisfacente. A maggio la Commissione europea ha evidenziato come il Piano Nazionale Integrato per l’Energia e il Clima (PNIEC) dell’Italia abbia al suo interno gravi carenze rispetto agli obiettivi climatici europei e alle raccomandazioni già formulate nel 2023. La valutazione conferma come l’Italia si mostri inadempiente, recependo solo parzialmente le indicazioni di Bruxelles e mancando l’occasione di colmare davvero le profonde lacune già emerse nella versione preliminare del piano. Anche sull’adattamento l’Italia è al palo: non solo non ha nemmeno avviato l’attuazione del Piano nazionale di Adattamento ai Cambiamenti Climatici approvato alla fine del 2023, ma nella legge di Bilancio in discussione in Parlamento risultano ulteriormente tagliati i fondi per affrontare il dissesto idrogeologico. Tutto questo mentre invece l’azione dell’esecutivo si concentra su progetti inutili, dannosi e costosi come il Ponte sullo Stretto di Messina, non a caso recentemente bocciato dalla Corte dei conti. Più in generale il WWF denuncia come il governo sembri deciso a ritardare il più possibile le azioni contro la crisi climatica in nome di un falso pragmatismo che rischia di danneggiare non solo il contrasto alla crisi climatica, ma la stessa competitività economica del Paese. Da quando il governo si è insediato abbiamo visto molte barriere e un forte rallentamento dello sviluppo delle energie rinnovabili, la soluzione per sostituire la causa del problema, cioè i combustibili fossili.

The catalogue contains a comprehensive list of information products relevant to the various Copernicus services.

Learn more

On January 27, 2025, clumps of solidified vegetable oil were found along a 25 km stretch of coastline on Finland’s Hanko Peninsula. While not toxic, the substance posed risks to wildlife. Suspecting it came from a passing vessel’s cargo tank wash, Finnish authorities launched an investigation,…

The COSNORTH-SEMAR DSS is a decision-support system developed to enhance maritime surveillance and law enforcement along Spain’s northern coast. Created in collaboration with the Guardia Civil, it combines environmental data, vessel tracking, and predictive modeling in a user-friendly platform…

Planning a sailing route based on weather used to be hard and needed expert skills. Many sailors didn’t use it because it was too complicated. SailRouting changes that by offering an easy online tool that shows weather-based routes in just a few clicks — no setup needed.

With SailRouting…

This study examines the environmental conditions near the Motagua River mouth in the Caribbean Sea, focusing on mangrove resilience, plastic pollution, and water turbidity. Photosynthesis data reveals magrove strong resistance with high absorption values in northern and southern regions, though…

🌍 A dust storm from North Africa swept across the W Mediterranean on 14 Nov.🛰️ This #CopernicusEU Sentinel-3 image shows Saharan dust stretching north, partially obscuring Sardinia 🇮🇹 and Corsica 🇫🇷. 🔗 https://t.co/oXpiv2qpQN#ImageOfTheDay pic.twitter.com/uOnOZ8OmaQ

— Copernicus EU (@CopernicusEU) November 18, 2025

🚀3, 2, 1… Liftoff! #CopernicusEU Sentinel-6B is now in orbit!🌊From tracking sea levels to supporting marine services & safety, this mission delivers science with impact & trusted climate data - achieved through a strong transatlantic partnership.🔗https://t.co/sqnKZjq5lM pic.twitter.com/iYrutUSoYT

— Copernicus EU (@CopernicusEU) November 17, 2025

🛰️ This #ImageOfTheDay, acquired by a #CopernicusEU Sentinel-2 satellite on 25 Oct, shows a meandering stretch of the Ganges River in eastern India 🇮🇳Its braided channels shape floodplains and farmland across one of the world’s most vital - and densely populated - river basins. pic.twitter.com/M3MWowiixZ

— Copernicus EU (@CopernicusEU) November 16, 2025

items.title: Future exposure to moist heat extremes linked to soil dryness
items.body:
Download PDF

Article
    
        
            Open access

Published: 18 November 2025

Future exposure to moist heat extremes linked to soil dryness
                    Jingwei Zhou1, Dragan Milošević1,2 & Adriaan J. Teuling1

npj Climate and Atmospheric Science

volume 8, Article number: 374 (2025)
            Cite this article

Subjects
        
            Atmospheric scienceClimate changeClimate-change impactsClimate sciencesProjection and prediction

AbstractSoil moisture critically modulates moist heat via surface energy fluxes, impacting human health and ecosystems under climate change. Using CMIP6 models with or without interactive soil moisture, we dissect its global role. Moist heat is most severe in tropical and extra-tropical regions, with mid-latitudes showing >2.4 °C increases significantly amplified by soil moisture. Soil moisture dynamics intensify moist heat across most land regions, exhibiting strong negative correlations, especially in eastern South America and Central America. Conversely, diverse moist heat responses to soil moisture variations are found in the Arabian Peninsula and northern Africa. High moist heat generally coincides with high Bowen ratio and low soil moisture while low moist heat is generally found with low Bowen ratio and high moisture. Our findings also highlight exceptions exist where moist heat is not directly influenced by these factors. Critically, soil moisture changes are increasing global population exposure to wet-hot extremes in most regions.

Similar content being viewed by others
                
                    
                        
                            
                                
                                    
                                
                                
                                    
                                        Changes in event soil moisture-temperature coupling can intensify very extreme heat beyond expectations

                                        Disentangling contributions to past and future trends in US surface soil moisture

                                        Emergent constraints on global soil moisture projections under climate change

                        IntroductionThe increasing frequency and intensity of moist heat extremes, driven by climate change, are exerting profound impacts on ecosystems, human health, and infrastructure1,2,3. Analysis by Fan et al. (2024) projects an increase in both frequency and intensity of moist heat extremes for most global regions by mid-century (2041–2060) and late-century (2081–2100) relative to the 1995–2014 baseline4. In comparison to dry heatwaves, moist heatwaves are particularly dangerous due to their impact on human physiology, leading to increased incidence of heat-related illnesses and mortality5,6. Approximately one billion people living in urban informal settlements globally are found to be threatened by moist heat extremes7. Soil moisture trends have the possibility to change their impacts on moist heat dynamics under climate change8. Global soil moisture content is found to have roughly equal proportions of drying and wetting in the past decades9, primarily drying regions in broadleaved forests and cropland areas10. While soil moisture trends display marked heterogeneity across soil strata and geographical regions, projections show that global land area is expected to exhibit significant soil moisture reductions11.Soil moisture is a pivotal variable in land-atmosphere interactions, significantly influencing the partitioning of near-surface energy fluxes, which in turn affects both temperature and humidity in the lower atmosphere12,13,14. To quantify moist heat extremes, temperature and relative humidity are the most reliable indicators, as both factors are crucial in the dissipation of heat from the human body through direct heat transfer and sweat evaporation2,15. The impact of soil moisture on temperature has been well-documented over the past decades8,16,17. High soil moisture generally facilitates high evapotranspiration, thereby reducing the energy available for sensible heating. In contrast, low soil moisture conditions associated with drought and (semi-)arid conditions will shift the energy balance towards one that is dominated by sensible heat fluxes rather than evapotranspiration. Higher sensible heat fluxes can amplify heatwave temperatures13,18.Declining soil moisture in general induces higher near-surface air temperature13. However, a primary consequence of reduced soil water content is the suppression of evapotranspiration, which directly limits the amount of moisture transferred from the land surface to the atmosphere, thereby decreasing near-surface relative humidity (Fig. S1)14. In the meantime, warming effect caused by desiccation introduces a secondary, indirect mechanism that further diminishes relative humidity, as warmer air can hold more moisture. Therefore, the impact of soil moisture on moist heat is less straightforward due to the complex feedbacks in the atmospheric boundary layer involving temperature and humidity, and only few studies have attempted to unravel these feedbacks19. Comprehending the intricate relationship between soil moisture and moist heat stress is essential for accurately assessing and mitigating moist heat extremes. In our study, we focus on one widely used index—discomfort index (see Identification and Classification of Moist Heat in Methods), to measure moist heat stress20,21,22,23. The metric incorporates both temperature and relative humidity, providing a measure of heat stress and tolerance levels among populations.Timing of extreme moist heat is critical to accurately assess its global risk. The conventional approach of analyzing a fixed, hemisphere-dependent season (e.g., May to September in northern hemisphere while November to March in southern hemisphere) is inadequate24, as it fails to capture the true period of peak climatological danger in many densely populated and highly vulnerable regions3. For instance, in monsoonal climates such as South Asia, the most life-threatening combinations of heat and humidity frequently occur during the monsoon-onset months (May to July), sometimes before the summer peak25. Utilizing a fixed window would therefore systematically exclude the most severe events in these regions, leading to a substantial underestimation of true regional risk. Our method of dynamically identifying the local peak moist heat season (month with the highest moist heat ± one month) at the grid-cell level is therefore vital. It ensures the analysis is centered on the period of maximum physiological threat specific to each location, providing the necessary credibility to map human exposure to potentially lethal moist heat conditions globally.This study aims to investigate the impacts of soil moisture on moist heat stress at a global scale utilizing the Land Surface, Snow and Soil Moisture Model Intercomparison Project (LS3MIP) dataset within the sixth phase of the Coupled Model Intercomparison Project (CMIP6)26,27. By analyzing historical and future simulations from LS3MIP, we examine the spatial and temporal variations of soil moisture-moist heat coupling and identify regions most susceptible to moist heat stress. Through comparing experiments with or without interactive soil moisture, soil moisture is then isolated to display that its interactions with moist heat are particularly pronounced in hot and humid regions. To our knowledge, this study is the first in using the LS3MIP simulation from the CMIP6 dataset to present a global overview of the interactions between soil moisture and moist heat, in which different peak moist heat seasons are applied in different places. Our research offers novel insights into the role of soil moisture in modulating moist heat stress and underscores the necessity for more accurate representations of land surface processes and feedbacks in climate models. The findings of this study can help in the development of effective strategies to manage and mitigate moist heat risks, and protect vulnerable populations.ResultsValidation of Used CMIP6 DatasetCMIP6 data share similar spatial distributions of moist heat with fifth generation ECMWF atmospheric reanalysis of the global climate (ERA5)-land data (Fig. 1a, c). For example, in general, moist heat decreases as the latitudes increases, except for some high-altitude regions. In the high-altitude regions such as Qinghai-Tibet Plateau, Rocky Mountains, the Andes area, and Greenland, the moist heat is relatively lower than the surrounding areas. CMIP6 results are generally higher than those from ERA5-Land by a value lower than 4.5 °C. However, in those high-altitude regions, the bias between CMIP6 and ERA5-Land results are greater (Fig. 1e). Our selected domains include regions where bias between CMIP6 and ERA5-Land are relatively moderate (Fig. 1e).Fig. 1: Validation of moist heat and soil moisture-moist heat correlations in used CMIP6 datasets.a, b Moist heat a and soil moisture-moist heat correlations b of used CMIP6 datasets in 2000–2020 is depicted. c, d Similar to a, b but for ERA5-Land dataset. e, f Comparisons of moist heat e and soil moisture-moist heat correlations f between CMIP6 and ERA5-Land datasets (CMIP6 minus ERA5-Land). The extensions in color bars indicate values beyond the limits, otherwise, the values are within the limits. Oceans have been masked in white. MH denotes moist heat and SM denotes soil moisture.Full size imageRegarding soil moisture-moist heat correlations, the spatial distributions between CMIP6 and ERA5-Land are also similar (Fig. 1b, d). Most land regions have negative correlations while in Northern Africa and Arabian Peninsula the correlations are relatively positive (Fig. 1b, d). In the meantime, the bias of that correlation is moderate between CMIP6 and ERA5-Land (Fig. 1f). CMIP6 data show a higher correlation between soil moisture and moist heat compared with ERA5-Land data in most regions. By contrast, within Northern Africa and Arabian Peninsula, most regions reveals that correlations between soil moisture and moist heat are relatively lower in CMIP6 results than those in ERA5-Land (Fig. 1f).Global Moist Heat Hotspots and ChangesChanges and hotspots of global moist heat are investigated using validated climate model data. In the current period (2000–2030), the tropics and extra-tropical regions consistently exhibit more severe moist heat conditions compared to other global areas (Fig. 2a). However, a notable increase in the intensity of moist heat is found in mid-latitude regions (Fig. 2c, S2a–h, q–x, and gg-nn; for example, in Fig. S2f, moist heat intensity is increasing, and in Fig. S2r, more frequent normal wet-hot days become possible in the future), surpassing the magnitude observed in the tropics and extra-tropical regions. These mid-latitude areas, traditionally associated with more temperate climates, are projected to experience significantly more frequent moist heat days in the future (Fig. S2q–x and gg-nn; for example, Fig. S2 shows more normal/extreme wet-hot days in different domains). Nevertheless, tropical and extra-tropical regions still experience a higher intensity and frequency of discomfort indices that exceeds thresholds (the fourth (27 °C)/fifth level (29 °C); Fig. 2b and S2a–h, q–x, and gg-nn).Fig. 2: Changes in moist heat over the 21st century.a, b Moist heat severity is depicted in current period (a; 2000–2030), and future period (b; 2040–2070). c Projected changes of moist heat across two 30-year periods (2000–2030 and 2040–2070). Hatching indicates where the differences between two periods are statistically significant (when p value < 0.05, the differences are regarded as significant; c; AD test). The extensions in color bars indicate values beyond the limits, otherwise, the values are within the limits. Oceans have been masked in white.Full size imageThe severity of these moist heat conditions highlights the elevated risk of moist heat-related health impacts in certain domains (Fig. 2a), making them key areas of concern in the context of global climate change. The domains, East, South, and Southeast Asia (ESEA), Australia (AU), Eastern United States (EUS), Central America (CAM), Arabian Peninsula (ARP), Mediterranean region and Northern Africa (MNAF), and Eastern South America (ESA), have been identified as hotspots for moist heat stress in our research.Soil Moisture Impacts on Moist HeatSoil moisture impacts on moist heat are studied as well as changes in moist heat per se. Negative, albeit not negligible, correlations between soil moisture and moist heat are found across most terrestrial regions (Fig. 3a, b). In ESA and CAM domains, negative correlations observed are notably stronger compared to other global regions exhibiting negative correlations (Fig. 3a, b), where the ongoing soil desiccation continues to amplify moist heat extremes in the future (Fig. 2, S2 and S3). By contrast, relatively positive correlations between soil moisture and moist heat are found within the ARP, MNAF, and eastern part of EUS domains (Fig. 3a, b), which is particularly noteworthy as it contrasts with the more commonly observed negative correlations in other domains, suggesting unique climatic interactions at play in the ARP and MNAF domains, where water availability and heat stress are critical concerns. Although significant correlations between soil moisture and moist heat are found over many regions, our analysis did not reveal strong correlations (>0.75 or <−0.75) across the studied domains, indicating that the relationship between these two variables are quasi-linear and affected by conflicting factors (Fig. 3, S1, and S3).Fig. 3: Contribution of soil moisture to moist heat.a, b Correlations between soil moisture anomalies and moist heat anomalies are depicted in current period (a; 2000–2030), and future period (b; 2040–2070). Anomalies are quantified using two experiments to avoid co-varying signals of both experiments (see CMIP6 data in Methods for detailed explanations of the two experiments). Hatching indicates where correlations are significant (when p value < 0.05 we can reject that soil moisture anomalies and moist heat anomalies have no correlations; Spearman rho test).c, d Soil moisture impacts over current period (a; 2000–2030), and future period (b; 2040–2070). e Contribution of soil moisture to projected changes of moist heat across two 30-year periods (2000–2030 and 2040–2070). Hatching indicates where the differences between two experiments (c, d; see CMIP6 data in Methods for detailed explanations of the two experiments) or two periods (e) are statistically significant (when p value < 0.05, the differences are regarded as significant; c, d, and e; AD test). The extensions in color bars indicate values beyond the limits, otherwise, the values are within the limits. Oceans have been masked in white.Full size imageTwo experiments (one is with interactive soil moisture and the other is with climatological values of soil moisture back in 1980–2014) in each of the climate model utilized are compared to isolate the impacts from soil moisture on moist heat. It is found that soil moisture tends to intensify moist heat at mostly mid-latitude regions in both periods (2000–2030 and 2040–2070; Fig. 3c, d). Conversely, Arabian Peninsula and northern Africa exhibit predominantly negative soil moisture effects on moist heat (Fig. 3c, d). Positive contributions from soil moisture trend and variability to projected increases of moist heat across two periods are found over most land regions (Fig. 3e). In South America, Caribbean regions, western and midwestern US, Alaska, and in particular southern Europe, regional hot spots exist where the influences of soil moisture on projected increases of moist heat are stronger compared with other regions (Fig. 3e).Complex and region-specific impacts from soil moisture on moist heat are found across different domains. However, high levels of moist heat are generally associated with a high Bowen ratio and low soil moisture, indicating that in dry conditions, more energy is partitioned into sensible heat and moist heat is amplified (Fig. 4 and S4–S12; high and low values, in terms of intensity rather than frequency, of different variables, are quantified locally; for example, in ESA, high Bowen ratio >1, low soil moisture <700 kg/m2, and high moist heat >24 °C; in MNAF, high Bowen ratio >40, low soil moisture <500 kg/m2, and high moist heat >26 °C). However, it is also shown that a high Bowen ratio is not always necessary for the manifestation of high moist heat when soil moisture is already limited (Fig. 4a, c, S4, S5, and Fig. S7–S10; high and low values, in terms of intensity rather than frequency, of different variables, are quantified locally; for example, in ARP, low Bowen ratio <3, low soil moisture <200 kg/m2, and high moist heat >28 °C; in AU, low Bowen ratio <1, low soil moisture <400 kg/m2, and high moist heat >24 °C). Conversely, relatively low moist heat conditions are typically accompanied by high soil moisture and a low Bowen ratio, especially in ESA and CAM (S7 and S8; high and low values, in terms of intensity rather than frequency, of different variables, are quantified locally, for example, in CAM, low Bowen ratio <0.1, high soil moisture >600 kg/m2, and low moist heat <26 °C). In these scenarios, abundant soil moisture contributes to a greater proportion of latent heat flux, in which evaporative cooling results in less severe moist heat conditions. This interplay between soil moisture, Bowen ratio, and moist heat highlights the critical role of soil moisture in modulating regional climate dynamics, particularly under varying soil moisture availability. Representative domains with high moist heat levels and high increases of population exposure to moist heat are shown here to roughly classify three kinds of soil moisture interactions with moist heat (ESEA: a negative soil moisture-moist heat correlation; ARP: a relatively positive soil moisture-moist heat correlation; EUS: a negative soil moisture-moist heat correlation, while the conditions are common where moist heat and soil moisture are both low; high and low values, in terms of intensity rather than frequency, of different variables, are quantified locally, for example, in EUS, low Bowen ratio <0.3, low soil moisture <700 kg/m2, and low moist heat <22 °C).Fig. 4: Regional analyses of moist heat.a, c, e Occurrences of soil moisture, Bowen ratio, and moist heat in ESEA a, ARP c, and EUS e are displayed for future period (2040–2070). Occurrences here are denoted by frequency (%). The occurrences in which Bowen ratio is above 0 and falls in the lower 90% are included. The moist heat within each box is the mean value of the all the occurrences which fall in the respective ranges of Bowen ratio and soil moisture. We use daily heat fluxes and soil moisture data from two climate models (IPSL-CM6 and MPI-ESM; Tab S1) as they are not available in CMCC of LS3MIP. The extensions in color bars indicate values beyond the limits, otherwise, the values are within the limits. The regional values shown here are area-weighted. The domains are delineated in Figs. 1, 2, 5, and S3, the oceans are excluded for these domains. b, d, f, Distributions of moist heat in ESEA (b), ARP (d), and EUS (f) are depicted. The distributions contain the upper 80% of the moist heat to discard the moist heat conditions which cause less harms on human health. The most common moist heat under both CTL and pdLC in the two periods are listed respectively. Current period is 2000–2030 and future period is 2040–2070.Full size imageIn ESEA, high moist heat is possible when Bowen ratio is high and soil moisture is low (Fig. 4a and S4; high and low values, in terms of intensity rather than frequency, of different variables, are quantified locally, for example, high Bowen ratio >0.6, low soil moisture <900 kg/m2, and high moist heat >26 °C). When the soil moisture is high, it will also mediate near-surface air temperature and moist heat, forming a negative correlation between soil moisture and moist heat. By contrast, a less strong but still negative correlation between soil moisture and moist heat is found over EUS (Fig. 3a, b). Nevertheless, in EUS, one aspect different from other domains is that moist heat is in general low when the Bowen ratio and soil moisture are both low (Fig. 4e and S6), which deduces the fact that we can’t overlook dry environments where both near-surface air temperature and relative humidity are low.In ARP, the situations where high Bowen ratio, low soil moisture, and high moist heat concurrently happen are not evidently dominating, while high moist heat can still happen with high soil moisture (Fig. 4c and S5). Despite soil desiccation accompanied with high Bowen ratio still tends to induce high moist heat, limited soil moisture-temperature interactions lead to minimal mediation of near-surface air temperatures (Fig. S13)17. Accordingly, especially when Bowen ratio is low and soil moisture is not severely limited, moist heat is more influenced by relative humidity compared with other domains. In the meantime, as higher relative humidity increases moist heat (Fig. S1), higher relative humidity is accompanied by relatively higher soil moisture and in this way facilitates a moderate but positive correlation between soil moisture and moist heat, especially in some regions of ARP and MNAF (Figs. 3,4, S5, and S10).Comparative analysis between current and future periods clearly indicates a worsening of the moist heat conditions across all studied domains (Fig. 4 and S4–S12). In the future period, the most common levels of moist heat exceed the thresholds typically associated with normal wet-hot days (for example, in ESEA, 27.1 °C > 27 °C, Fig. 4b; in ARP, 28 °C > 27 °C, Fig. 4d) in most domains. The only two potential exceptions appear to be EUS and CAM (Fig. 4, S6, and S8), where the most common levels of moist heat are below 27 °C, but the escalation of moist heat still makes substantial wet-hot days. These findings point to an alarming future where the baseline for moist heat is dramatically higher, presenting severe implications for regional climate dynamics, human health, and agriculture. One thing to note here is that sometimes the common moist heat (Fig. 3b, d, f) does not indicate expected results of soil moisture-moist heat interactions. For example, in ESEA, common moist heat in uncoupled experiments is higher than that in coupled experiments (Fig. 4b), suggesting soil desiccation doesn’t necessarily induce a higher moist heat in ESEA in both periods. However, general distributions in coupled experiments are found with more occurrences of severe moist heat compared with those in uncoupled ones (Fig. 4b).Increasing Population Exposure to Moist HeatPopulation exposure to humid heatwaves is another focus of our study. A substantial increase in the population exposed to more than 6 days for average normal humid heatwave during the maxima season is found across numerous regions in the selected domains (Fig. 5a), driven by growing population in some regions and rising global moist heat. However, an exception to this trend is observed in AU and some parts in CAM and ESA (Fig. 5a), where the data suggest no increases or less increases in the number of people exposed to these hazardous conditions in the future compared to the current period. Despite these localized situations, most domains experience significant increases in population exposed to average humid heatwave reaching a dangerous moist heat level (>27 °C).Fig. 5: Projected changes of population exposure to moist heat.a Changes of population count which will be exposed to seasonally mean normal humid heatwave duration above 6 days across the current period (2000, 2010, 2020, and 2030) and future period (2040, 2050, 2060, and 2070). The extensions in color bars indicate values beyond the limits, otherwise, the values are within the limits. b–g, and h, Changes of population percentage exposed to seasonally mean humid heatwave duration above 6 days and related soil moisture contributions. The regional values shown here are area-weighted. The oceans are excluded for these domains. HH indicates humid heatwaves.Full size imageAcross all analyzed domains, climate model data reveal a clear and consistent trend of increasing population exposure to average humid heatwave longer than 6 days (Fig. 5). Each subplot in Fig. 5 demonstrates a marked upward trajectory in the percentage of the population affected by these moist heat conditions. ESEA, ARP, and MNAF are identified as the domains facing the most severe moist heat conditions. In these domains, during current period (2000–2030), population exposure to average normal humid heatwaves is in general already more than 20%, in ESEA and ARP, the current situation is more severe as the population exposure to average normal humid heatwaves can be more than 40% (Fig. 5c, d). In the future period of these domains, population exposure to average normal humid heatwave longer than 6 days could reach as high as 80% by 2060, with some domains, such as ARP, potentially having 80% of their population exposure to humid heatwaves since 2030 (Fig. 5c). In the meantime, in ESEA, the situation is serious but expected to happen later, with population exposure to average extreme humid heatwave longer than 6 days reaching 50% by 2070 (Fig. 5d). The high levels of exposure projected for these domains underscore the critical need for immediate and sustained efforts to enhance moist heat mitigation, particularly for vulnerable regions most at risk from the health impacts of extreme heat.While people in EUS and ESA are projected to experience comparatively less severe moist heat conditions than domains like ESEA, ARP, and MNAF, the outlook remains concerning. By 2070, it is anticipated that population exposure to average normal humid heatwave longer than 6 days will be over 50% in both EUS and ESA (Fig. 5b, f), which still represents a substantial public health challenge. In CAM and AU domains, the projected increases in population exposure to moist heat are less pronounced compared to other domains. However, in CAM, for example, more than 20% of the population is projected to be exposed to average normal humid heatwave longer than 6 days since 2060 (Fig. 5e), which highlights the importance of maintaining awareness and preparedness in CAM and AU. In those places, the impacts of moist heat, though less severe in scale, could still pose significant risks to public health and human well-being.Soil moisture changes predominantly amplify population exposure to average humid heatwave longer than 6 days in all the domains with notable exceptions in the ARP and MNAF (Fig. 5c, g). The temporal dynamics of soil moisture contributions to population exposure to moist heat vary regionally: ESEA experiences stronger effects during the present period and does not show an increasing trend with soil moisture impacts (Fig. 5d), while intensifications of soil moisture contributions are projected in EUS, CAM, and ESA (Fig. 5b, e, f). In EUS, ESEA, and ESA, soil moisture changes amplify population exposure to moist heat more significantly compared with other domains (Fig. 5b, d, f), for example, more than 10% of the local population of ESEA exposed to average extreme humid heatwave longer than 6 days are caused by soil moisture changes in 2000 (Fig. 5d). In contrast, AU shows minimal soil moisture-driven population exposure to moist heat events, with less than 3% of its population affected by soil moisture changes in general (Fig. 5h).DiscussionThe increasing intensity of moist heat is found across various domains (Figs. 2, 4, S2, and S4-S12). All selected domains show an increasing trend in moist heat and wet-hot days, particularly in mid-latitude areas (Fig. 2 and S2). The observed increases in these domains suggest a broader geographic expansion of extreme moist heat conditions, which highlights the emerging vulnerability of mid-latitude regions to moist heat extremes. To understand moist heat trend, soil moisture is critical in its role of influencing regional climate responses. Across many domains, soil moisture changes, including long-term trend of soil moisture and its short-term variability, contribute more to the regional changes of moist heat than the global average (Fig. S2).The relationship between soil moisture and moist heat is not uniform across domains. In current period (2000–2030), the effects of both soil moisture variability and trend are most significant across the MNAF, ESEA, AU, and ESA (Fig. 3c). Differences of soil moisture between pdLC and CTL lead to more responses in moist heat in the future period (2040–2070) across those domains (Fig. 3d, e). Predominantly (semi-)arid regions such as ARP and MNAF indicate that soil moisture increases could potentially mitigate the intensity of moist heat and reduce the frequency of wet-hot days (Fig. 4d, S2, S3, S5b and S10b). Nevertheless, with increasing soil moisture trends (Fig. S3)28,29, mediating effects of soil moisture have a limit and do not change much (soil moisture effects even become less mitigating in some regions; Fig. 3c–e and S2) as expected (more soil moisture increases are accompanied with more moist heat mitigation if the correlation between soil moisture and moist heat is negative), which conforms the fact that positive correlations are found over some regions in ARP and MNAF (Fig. 3a, b). These findings are consistent with some former research results, in which elevated surface humidity are caused by relatively higher soil moisture and increased latent heat flux2,19. Moreover, the advection of humid air masses from neighboring water bodies, such as the Mediterranean Sea or the Red Sea, when combined with high solar radiation and specific boundary layer conditions, may provide the necessary moisture that leads to the observed moderate but positive soil moisture-moist heat correlation in some places2.Sometimes increases in moist heat are not necessarily driven by additional local surface drying with a higher Bowen ratio (Fig. 4a, c, S4, S5, and S7–S10), suggesting that factors other than dry soil can lead to significant thermal stress without further increases in the Bowen ratio. Instead, large-scale atmospheric dynamics often become the dominant factor in leading to significant moist heat stress. By remaining in place for days or even weeks, a blocking high creates a heat dome effect. This pattern leads to prolonged clear skies, allowing for maximum solar radiation, and causes subsidence, where air from higher places in the atmosphere sinks. Lower surface albedo compared with desert in coastal areas also facilitates heating. As the air sinks, it is compressed and warmed adiabatically, significantly increasing surface temperatures over a vast area independent of local soil moisture changes30. The horizontal transport of air, or advection, is another critical factor. Hot, dry air masses originating from desert regions or continental interiors can be transported over long distances. This influx of a pre-heated air mass can rapidly and dramatically increase local temperatures. In such cases, the extreme heat is imported rather than generated by local land-atmosphere energy exchanges, meaning severe moist heat can occur without further changes in the local Bowen ratio31.Similar effects are also particularly pronounced in low-elevation, coastal regions (Fig. S14) of ESEA, AU, CAM, and ESA, where clear skies yield strong solar radiation and contribute to severe moist heat conditions2. Therefore, high moist heat is possible when both Bowen ratio and soil moisture are low (Fig. 4, S4, and S7–S9). However, ESEA, AU, CAM, and ESA exhibit a broader range of soil moisture levels. On the one hand, continuing soil desiccation tends to amplify moist heat in the future (Fig. 4a, e, S2, S4b, and S7b-S9b), from which it is deduced that maintaining soil moisture close to climatological values could further reduce extreme heat (Fig. S3; see Detection of Soil Moisture Impacts on Moist Heat in Methods for detailed explanations of the experimental setting). On the other hand, even though higher soil moisture increases evaporation, thereby enhancing relative humidity, it will also mediate near-surface air temperature and in this way moist heat with soil moisture-temperature interactions, which are more evident in ESA and CAM (Figs. S7 and S8). Therefore, moist heat is inhibited with more soil moisture, which facilitate a negative correlation between soil moisture and moist heat, especially in ESA and CAM (Fig. 3, S7, and S8). In conclusion, the complex interplay between soil moisture, near-surface air temperature, and relative humidity underpins the distribution of moist heat across different domains. This interplay underscores the critical role of soil moisture in modulating heat stress and highlights the urgent need for region-specific mitigation strategies to address the escalating impacts of climate change. These findings emphasize the need for more nuanced climate models that can accurately simulate the non-linear and localized interactions between soil moisture and atmospheric conditions.People in most domains are found to be facing more frequent and severe moist heat events (Fig. 5 and S15). The impending threat needs to be recognized in local ability to cope with humid heatwaves and expedite the implementation of mitigating facilities, such as air conditioning systems and urban green spaces, which are crucial for reducing moist heat stress32,33. Interestingly, domains like AU and CAM are expected to see relatively smaller increases in population exposure to moist heat. This is partly due to the fact that, in many areas of both domains, average humid heatwave during maxima seasons will not reach 6 days. However, it is important to note that even in these domains, albeit less than 6 days of all the humid heatwave occurrences during maxima seasons, severe moist heat events remain possible, warranting timely and comprehensive strategies at both governmental and individual levels. In addition, in AU, the projected increases in moist heat are concentrated primarily in inland areas, which are less densely populated compared to coastal regions. Impacts of soil moisture on population exposure to humid heatwaves exhibit complex spatial patterns. Although in most areas, soil moisture changes tend to contribute to more population exposed to humid heatwaves. In MNAF and ARP, soil moisture changes sometimes mitigate population exposure by dampening moist heat (Fig. 3c, d and Fig. 5c, g), though this effect is partly offset in southern Europe due to relatively positive soil moisture-moist heat feedbacks (Fig. 3c, d). In EUS, the continued great contributions from soil moisture post-2000 can be attributed to higher impacts from soil moisture in the middle part (Fig. 3). Additionally, contributions from soil moisture on population exposure to moist heat (Fig. 5) are related to soil moisture’s variations relative to its climatological values (Fig. S3). In domains where soil desiccation strongly amplifies moist heat such as CAM and ESA, soil moisture is projected to decrease and in this way facilitates more population exposure in the future (Fig. 5 and S3).We conclude that our results provided by CMIP6 datasets are a qualitatively robust representation of the large-scale global patterns of the evaluated variables. Bias of moist heat between CMIP6 and ERA5-Land results are moderate, with most regions having a bias lower than 4.5 °C (Fig. 1e). However, in MNAF and ARP, correlations between soil moisture and moist heat are generally lower in CMIP6 compared with ERA5-Land (Fig. 1f), which indicates those positive correlations should be greater but not reflected in our CMIP6 results. Similarly, underestimations of correlations between soil moisture and moist heat exist in other domains. As most regions have negative correlations, the positive bias between CMIP6 and ERA5-Land indicates that the correlations between soil moisture and moist heat ought to be more negative and thus relatively stronger.A critical source of discrepancy lies in the parameterization of soil hydrology. For instance, climate models do not have the same setting of soil profile, they might differ, and in this way have different representation of the soil moisture34,35,36,37. In high-altitude regions, climate models show deficiencies in simulating cold-region hydrological processes, such as the thawing of snowpack and frozen ground. These processes can introduce large volumes of water into the soil column, and misrepresentations of those can lead to significant biases in soil moisture, energy fluxes, and thus moist heat dynamics during the summer season38,39.The choice of maxima season for studying moist heat stress is crucial for accurately assessing the potential impacts on human health and infrastructure. To our knowledge, our study is pioneering in its adoption of different maxima seasons for different regions, which allows us to focus on the periods when moist heat stress is most likely to endanger human health. Moreover, the top 10% of extreme conditions is focused on when evaluating moist heat. This approach ensures that our analysis captures the highest potential impacts, as extreme moist heat events near their upper thresholds are most critical for public health.Effective land management is critical for mitigating humid heatwave impacts on human populations. Irrigation is often highlighted for its ability to modify local soil moisture and reduce temperature extremes, potentially decreasing heatwave exposure for 0.79 to 1.29 billion people40. However, the benefits of irrigation are not universal. In regions where soil moisture and moist heat are positively correlated, particularly where relative humidity exerts more influence, irrigation may inadvertently increase heat stress by raising air humidity (Fig. 3 and S14)41,42. Additionally, water scarcity in arid regions further limits the feasibility of widespread irrigation43,44. While irrigation may be effective in some areas, its use must be carefully calibrated to avoid exacerbating moist heat stress in certain regions.Our analysis is intentionally constrained to the role of soil moisture as a foundational, large-scale driver to moist heat extremes through comparing two experiments with different soil moisture setting (see Detection of Soil Moisture Impacts on Moist Heat in Methods). We acknowledge, however, that a complete picture of moist heat modulation requires considering additional anthropogenic or natural forcings. For example, future investigations should integrate the impacts of urbanization, which is a significant driver of observed surface warming at local and regional scales, altering thermal and humidity regimes45. Moreover, a meta-analysis of numerous studies confirms that urban green spaces provide measurable cooling benefits, though their magnitude can vary significantly with park size and vegetation type46. Anthropogenic aerosols are also important factors which influence regional temperature and humidity, through modifying the solar radiation, cloud properties, and precipitation47. A systematic assessment of how these distinct yet interacting drivers collectively modulate the soil moisture-driven moist heat signal is a crucial further step for a holistic risk assessment.In addition, future work will aim to disentangle soil moisture impacts on moist heat by distinguishing between short-term transient fluctuations and long-term drying trends. High-resolution data could complement this analysis by revealing how the variability of soil moisture across different time scales either amplifies or dampens humid heatwaves. However, the broad geographical domains used in this study occasionally mask significant intra-regional heterogeneity in soil moisture’s impact on moist heat. Incorporating higher spatial resolution in climate models would therefore allow future studies to better capture the nuanced interactions between soil moisture and moist heat, particularly in urban environments. Fine-scale spatial differences are critical in evaluating urban settings where microclimates can vary dramatically over short distances due to factors like building density, green space distribution, and water bodies48,49. Higher resolution will enable researchers to better understand how moist heat stress interacts with urban infrastructure and population density and thus identify localized vulnerabilities to moist heat. Moreover, refining the spatial resolution of climate models will facilitate more accurate predictions of moist heat-related impacts on public health and the effectiveness of mitigation strategies such as urban greening and land management practices.MethodsCMIP6 DataIn this study, we utilized daily near-surface air temperature, near-surface relative humidity, surface sensible heat flux, surface latent heat flux, and total soil moisture in the historical experiment, the Shared Socioeconomic Pathway (SSP) 585 experiment in Scenario Model Intercomparison Project (ScenarioMIP)50,51, and LFMIP-pdLC experiment of LS3MIP27 from three climate models within CMIP626 (Tab. S1). CMIP6 dataset used in this research has demonstrated robust performance in capturing global soil moisture dynamics and land-atmosphere coupling strength8,27,52,53. LS3MIP is a coordinated experimental framework intended to elucidate the complex interplay between terrestrial surface processes, especially soil moisture, and climate dynamics. This project is set to reveal the critical role of those land surface-climate interactions in affecting atmospheric conditions and modulating extreme events including heatwaves and droughts27. Scenario MIP and historical experiment from CMIP6 is widely used in numerous former studies8,54. The analysis of historical and ScenarioMIP data, referred to hereafter as CTL, minus the LFMIP-pdLC results allows us to isolate the effects of soil moisture changes on moist heat by accounting for both (a) the removal of multidecadal and interannual soil moisture trends and (b) the exclusion of short-term soil moisture variations on sub-seasonal timescale. For consistency, all climate model datasets were interpolated onto a common grid of 2.5° longitude by 1.875° latitude using a conservative remapping technique55. This interpolation enabled the use of a multi-model ensemble mean in our analysis. Only three climate models are chosen because of the availability of daily variable data in both CTL and LFMIP-pdLC experiments.Detection of Soil Moisture Impacts on Moist HeatEach of three climate models from the CMIP6 dataset (please refer to CMIP6 data of Methods for further details on the models) has a fully-coupled control run (CTL) and two experiments (pdLC and rmLC) where soil moisture is prescribed. In this paper, we focus on the pdLC experiment alongside the CTL to quantify the effects of soil moisture changes, represented as CTL–pdLC. CTL experiment features fully coupled and interactive soil moisture. In the corresponding pdLC experiment, by prescribing a repeating seasonal climatology of soil moisture derived from the 1980–2014 control simulation, soil moisture influences can be isolated (detailed information on the CMIP6 experiments can be found in CMIP6 data of Methods)27. Crucially, both simulations are forced with identical sea surface temperature and sea ice conditions, ensuring that any divergence in their outputs can be attributed solely to the soil moisture variability27. To investigate the contribution of soil moisture changes to moist heat and population exposure to it, we examine the comparative moist heat estimates between CTL and pdLC. Soil moisture impacts on moist heat (°C) and population exposure (%) are quantified in this research accordingly.Statistical significance in moist heat comparisons between the present period (2000–2030) and the future period (2040–2070), as well as between CTL and pdLC, is determined using the Anderson-Darling test (AD test)56. The decision to compare the period of 2000–2030 with the nearer future period of 2040–2070, rather than a historical period with a more distant future such as 2070–2100, ensures a more relevant investigation of changes in moist heat levels and population exposure to moist heat events. The correlations between soil moisture and moist heat are quantified using the Spearman correlation coefficient57, with statistical significance assessed via the Spearman rho test58. These correlations are calculated using the bias between CTL and pdLC runs. The seasonality and climatological trend of soil moisture and moist heat, that is, co-varying signals of the two variables in both experiments, will be removed, facilitating identifications of possible non-linear relationships between soil moisture and moist heat.ERA5-Land DatasetThis study utilized the ERA5-Land global reanalysis dataset to validate the results from CMIP6 dataset. ERA5-Land is a product of the European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts (ECMWF) and provides a consistent, high-resolution view of land surface variables from 1950 to the near present59. It was generated by replaying the land component of the ERA5 climate reanalysis, driven by atmospheric forcing from the ERA5 atmospheric reanalysis. For consistency, ERA5-Land datasets were interpolated onto a common grid of 2.5° longitude by 1.875° latitude using a conservative remapping technique55.Near-surface air temperature (T), near-surface dewpoint temperature (Td), near-surface volumetric soil water (SM, %) from the depth 0–7 cm (SM1), 7–28 cm (SM2), 28–100 cm (SM3), and 100–289 cm (SM4) are used from ERA5-Land, but near-surface relative humidity is not directly available. In order to derive relative humidity, firstly saturation vapor pressure is calculated as60:$${SVP}(T)=6.1094\times {e}^{\frac{17.625\times T}{243.04+T}}$$
                    (1)
                Near-surface relative humidity is then defined as the ratio of the actual vapor pressure to the saturation vapor pressure at the current near-surface air temperature:$${RH}=\frac{{e}^{\frac{17.625\times {T}_{d}}{243.04+{T}_{d}}}\,}{{e}^{\frac{17.625\times T}{243.04+T}}\,}\times 100$$
                    (2)
                CTL and pdLC differ in total soil moisture (water summed over all soil layers), which is not available in ERA5-Land datasets. Therefore, from ERA5-Land datasets, we summed all layers’ volumetric soil water content (%) multiplied by its respective layer depth and water density to generate the total soil moisture (kg/m2).Definition of DomainsTo enhance the characterization of regional soil moisture effects, we utilize the updated climate reference regions from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change’s Sixth Assessment Report (IPCC AR6). These regions are delineated based on consistent regional climate characteristics derived from both observational data and climate modelling (CMIP6) datasets61. Seven domains are set for this study: East, South, and Southeast Asia (ESEA), Australia (AU), Eastern United States (EUS), Central America (CAM), Arabian Peninsula (ARP), Mediterranean region and Northern Africa (MNAF), and Eastern South America (ESA) (Figs. 1, 2, 5, and S3).Identification and Classification of Moist HeatMany different methods and indices exist to quantify moist heat22,62,63. Here, we use a discomfort index (DI) to classify moist heat64 (21–24 °C, <50% of population in discomfort; 24–27 °C, >50% of population in discomfort; 27–29 °C, most of the population in discomfort; 29–32 °C, everyone feels severe stress; >32 °C, state of emergency)22,65. DI serves as a robust metric for quantifying perceived thermal stress, derived from empirical studies by the U.S. Weather Bureau. Critically, DI demonstrates strong correlation with physiological responses, particularly sweat rates during both rest and exercise, underscoring its relevance in assessing human thermal comfort and potential heat-related health risks66. Modified discomfort index (MDI) is not adopted as it doesn’t correspond to the widely used categories of discomfort we used in this research22,65,67. In addition, DI demonstrates remarkable concordance with the wet-bulb globe temperature (WBGT), a widely-used metric to measure moist heat22,62,63, exhibiting exceptionally high coefficients of determination66. However, necessary variables such as black globe temperature (Tg) and water vapor pressure to calculate WBGT are not available in the climate model dataset we used. As a result, DI is a more efficient metric ready to be used.To derive DI, wet-bulb temperature (WBT) needs to be calculated first. Historically, WBT calculations were computationally intensive, prompting the use of approximations of WBT68.$$\begin{array}{lll}WBT=T* \arctan \left(0.151977* \left({\left(\mathrm{rh}+8.313659\right)}^{1/2}\right)\right)\\\qquad\quad\;\;\,+\arctan \left(T+\mathrm{rh}\right)-\arctan \left(\mathrm{rh}-1.676331\right)\\\qquad\quad\;\;\,+\,0.00391838* \left({\mathrm{rh}}^{3/2}\right)* \arctan \left(0.023101* \mathrm{rh}\right)-4.686035\end{array}$$
                    (3)
                Discomfort index can then be expressed as:$${DI}=0.5* {WBT}+0.5* T$$
                    (4)
                where T is the near-surface 2 m air temperature, rh is the near-surface 2 m relative humidity as we focus on the impacts of moist heat on humans’ living condition. WBT is the wet-bulb temperature68. Days with moist heat above or equal with 27 °C and 29 °C are defined as normal wet-hot days and extreme wet-hot days according to the DI levels (Fig. 2a, b), respectively.Apart from tropical regions, moist heat extremes occur mainly from June to August in the Northern Hemisphere and from December to February in the Southern Hemisphere (Fig. S16). Tropical regions, influenced by consistent solar insolation and monsoonal patterns, generally have stable temperature and humidity69. However, monsoons can shift the timing of moist heat, with extreme moist heat preceding or following monsoons70,71. Therefore, we identified the month by ranking monthly mean moist heat values in each grid, focusing on the hottest month and its two adjacent months in our research. The relevant month and season are defined as maxima month and season. As no significant shifts are found in maxima month for moist-heat extremes across future scenarios (Fig. S16)4, we utilized consistent maxima seasons in current and future periods respectively.Our study uniquely adopts different maxima seasons across regions, focusing on the period of most severe moist heat stress. In addition, to quantify moist heat levels, we analyzed the top 10% of occurrences, which is crucial for understanding potential human impacts. When examining the relationship between soil moisture, Bowen ratio, and moist heat, we focused on occurrences where the Bowen ratio exceeds 0 and lies within the lower 90%. This approach minimizes the influences of outliers that skew the Bowen ratio distribution (Fig. S17).Population Dataset and ExposureGiven that population exposure to moist heat is influenced by both demographic factors and moist heat characteristics, our research integrates future population trends to reduce uncertainties in estimating changes in population exposure. To this end, we utilize gridded global population data for the years 2000, 2010, 2020, 2030, 2040, 2050, 2060, and 2070 to assess exposure to moist heat. The dataset, based on the data of 2000, aligns both quantitatively and qualitatively with the SSPs (specifically SSP585 in this study)72,73. The dataset’s spatial resolution is 1/8° by 1/8° in both longitude and latitude. To harmonize the spatial resolution and grid availability between climate and population projections, we aggregate the population data into 2.5° × 1.875° grids by summing the total population within the 1/8° × 1/8° grids that fall within each grid of climate data55. This interpolation facilitates the quantification of population exposure to moist heat, calculated as follows:$${{PE}}_{{percent}}={P}_{a}/{P}_{{all}}$$
                    (5)
                $${{PE}}_{a{bsolute}}={P}_{a}$$
                    (6)
                In a certain region, PEabsolute indicates the population count exposed to moist heat extremes. To better quantify the exposure of populations to increasing moist heat, we also adopted a percentage-based approach with respect to changing local population. In this way, the influences from the demographic shifts can be eliminated, which allows for a robust assessment of population exposure to moist heat. PEpercent indicates the exposed population percentage relative to the total population. Pa indicates the population count which is exposed to average humid heatwaves longer than a certain duration, Pall is the count of the total population.To investigate cumulative heat stress and human acclimatization, apart from solely moist heat stress measurements, we defined normal humid heatwaves as at least 3 consecutive days above 27 °C (normal wet-hot days) and extreme humid heatwaves for 29 °C (extreme wet-hot days). Seasonally humid heatwave duration is calculated as the mean value of each humid heatwave across the whole maxima season of a year. The population exposure to seasonally humid heatwave duration above 6 days and soil moisture impacts on it are quantified in this study.

Data availability
              
              Gridded data of global population count are available from SEDAC of NASA73. The CMIP6 model simulations are from Earth System Grid Federation (https://aims2.llnl.gov/search). ERA5-Land data are from Copernicus Climate Change Service (https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/datasets/derived-era5-land-daily-statistics?tab=download)59.

items.description: 50 morti e centinaia di migliaia di sfollati, migliaia di case distrutte tra Giamaica e altre isole dei Caraibi: questa l’eredità di Melissa, l’uragan
items.body:
Climate Risk Index 2026: il riscaldamento climatico tra i rischi principali

17.11.2025 -                                 Clima, Cambiamenti Climatici, Emissioni gas serra

condividi:

50 morti e centinaia di migliaia di sfollati, migliaia di case distrutte tra Giamaica e altre isole dei Caraibi: questa l’eredità di Melissa, l’uragano che ha raggiunto categoria 5 (la massima possibile), con venti fino a 300 km/h.

Talmaegi e Fung-Wong sono invece gli ultimi due tifoni (nel solo 2025 ce ne sono stati ben 21) che hanno devastato le Filippine nelle scorse settimane, provocando una decina di morti e portando all’evacuazione di 1 milione e 400 mila persone con danni stimati in oltre 4 miliardi di dollari.

Sono numeri davvero impressionanti, che vanno a confermare un trend che pone le Filippine tra i Paesi più colpiti da eventi estremi negli ultimi anni, così come riportato nel “Climate Risk Index 2026” presentato nel corso della COP 30 in corso a Belém che certifica in modo chiaro come uragani, tifoni e altri eventi estremi stiano diventando sempre più frequenti e intensi così come i loro effetti devastanti.

Il Climate Risk Index, pubblicato fin dal 2006, è un report sugli impatti climatici basato su un indice retrospettivo, che classifica i Paesi del Mondo in base ai danni subiti a causa degli eventi meteorologici estremi (numero di vittime e in generale di persone colpite, danni economici).

Si tratta di una pubblicazione curata da Germanwatch, Organizzazione tedesca indipendente che si occupa di sviluppo, ambiente e diritti umani che in oltre 30 anni di attività di advocacy ha realizzato più di 650 progetti in tutto il mondo spesso risultando fondamentali nel contesto delle politiche di azione per il clima.

Il ranking stila una classifica dei Paesi sulla base degli impatti economici e umani subiti, mettendo nelle prime posizioni chi ha subito maggiormente forti piogge (heavy rainfalls), tempeste devastanti (devastating storms), inondazioni mortali (deadly floods)ma anche caldo torrido (Scorching heat) e incendi (raging wildfires) che abbiano avuto effetti devastanti per le comunità, situazione diventata oggi fin troppo comune in alcuni contesti.

Tra il 1995 e il 2024, il periodo coperto dall'analisi dell'indice che di fatto è anche il trentennio in cui si è provato ad attivare una risposta globale alla crisi climatica tramite le COP, gli oltre 9.700 eventi meteorologici estremi che si sono verificati hanno causato più di 832.000 vittime e hanno portato a perdite economiche dirette per quasi 4,5 trilioni di dollari (valori economici non attualizzati).

L’edizione 2026 del Climate Risk Index https://www.germanwatch.org/en/93310 sottolinea il costo crescente dell'inazione in termini economici ma soprattutto di perdite umane ed evidenzia come la frequenza e l’intensità degli eventi e, di conseguenza, i loro effetti devastanti siano in continuo aumento.

Il ranking appena pubblicato mostra come i Paesi più colpiti da eventi estremi nel corso del 2024 siano stati Saint Vincent e Grenadine, Grenada, Chad, Papua Nuova Guinea, Niger e Nepal.

Se la valutazione si allarga all’intero periodo considerato 1995-2024, ai primi posti si ritrovano Repubblica Domenicana, Myanmar, Honduras, Libia e Haiti.

L’Italia in questa classifica è al sedicesimo posto su 174 paesi mappati.

Il grafico mostra i 20 paesi più colpiti in questo periodo in base ai sei indicatori CRI analizzati (quali: * numero assoluto di vittime; * vittime ogni 100.000 abitanti; * numero assoluto di persone colpite; * persone colpite ogni 100.000 abitanti; * perdite economiche assolute; * perdite economiche relative [in percentuale del PIL]).

Gli eventi estremi hanno una intensità ed una frequenza ("tempo di ritorno") sempre più alta nei medesimi territori, che fanno sempre più fatica a riprendersi tra un evento e l’altro: in termini tecnici significa che l'aumento dei fenomeni estremi abbassa la resilienza dei territori.

Un esempio molto vicino a noi è quanto verificatosi in Emilia-Romagna con le due alluvioni della primavera 2023 e dell’autunno 2024.

Per questo motivo la COP30 si conferma essere un appuntamento fondamentale per il futuro delle nostre comunità.

Il contrasto alla crisi climatica deve passare sia attraverso la mitigazione, vale a dire la riduzione tendente all’azzeramento delle emissioni di gas serra, ma è sempre più importante che ad essa si affianchino azioni di adattamento vale a dire una risposta efficace agli effetti che non è possibile evitare.
